channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Apple job listing mentions “homeOS” days before WWDC keynote
item.description: This is the first we’ve heard of an operating system called homeOS.

item.title: You can grab another 12 months of PlayStation Plus for $45 today
item.description: Dealmaster also has early Prime Day deals, free video games, and Instant Pots.

item.title: Garmin just announced an LTE capable Forerunner watch. We spent a week with it
item.description: Garmin’s LTE-connected watch is about safety while running. It’s not for talking.

item.title: HBO Max now offers a (partially) ad-supported service tier
item.description: If you’re willing to watch some ads, you can knock $5/mo off your service cost.

item.title: After months of drama, Minecraft speedrunner Dream admits he used mods
item.description: Dream says he “didn’t have any intention of cheating” in controversial speedruns.

item.title: Amazon Prime Day 2021 runs June 21-22, and a few deals are already live
item.description: The two-day sale event is back to its midsummer timeframe, on the heels of an announced MGM acquisition.

item.title: Launcher raises $11 million, ramps up hiring for 2024 flight
item.description: “Compared to our competitors, we are in the kindergarten of fundraising.”

item.title: Review: Nvidia RTX 3080 Ti is a powerhouse—but good luck finding it at $1,199 MSRP
item.description: $1,199 MSRP is arguably worth it—in a universe where MSRP means anything, at least.

item.title: AMD triples Zen 3 CPU cache using 3D stacking technology
item.description: Not a pipe dream—CEO Lisa Su demonstrated a working 3D-stacked 5900X prototype.

item.title: What the physics of skipping stones can tell us about aircraft water landings
item.description: A combination of gyro effect and Magnus effect influences the deflection of trajectory

item.title: Months from the release of Dune 2021, the 1984 version gets a 4K release
item.description: Lynch, who disowned the film, won’t be recording a commentary track.

item.title: Shortages loom as ransomware hamstrings the world’s biggest meat producer
item.description: Add meat to the list of critical supply chains disrupted by the malware scourge.

item.title: Big Tech sues Florida, saying social media law violates First Amendment
item.description: Facebook/Twitter lobby sues over law that protects politicians from “censorship.”

item.title: Xiaomi’s 200 W phone charger goes from 0-100% in 8 minutes
item.description: Charge a phone as quickly as gassing up a car.

item.title: Pirelli puts a wireless sensor in its new tire for the McLaren Artura
item.description: We ask Pirelli to explain its thinking behind the Cyber Tire.

item.title: After 75,000 Echo arbitration demands, Amazon now lets you sue it
item.description: IT-savvy law firms have swamped retailer with arbitration cases.

item.title: ROM site owner made $30,000 a year—now owes Nintendo $2.1M
item.description: The DMCA’s “safe harbor” isn’t so safe when you upload the files.

item.title: Webb telescope launch date slips again
item.description: We “don’t have a lot of reserve” left.

item.title: The US military is starting to get really interested in Starship
item.description: “The Air Force seeks to leverage the current multi-billion dollar commercial investment.”

item.title: The best Memorial Day sales we can find on laptops, video games, and more tech [Updated]
item.description: Including deals on Lenovo ThinkPads, wireless headphones, and PlayStation games.

item.title: Can we keep human inconsistency from confusing expert advice?
item.description: Human variability is great—except when it gets in the way of consistent guidance.

item.title: Genetic tricks of the longest-lived animals
item.description: By studying long-living animals, researchers hope to pinpoint factors affecting human longevity.

item.title: Building a better edible
item.description: Scientists are scouring existing studies and research to learn how edibles interact with the body.

item.title: Movie written by algorithm turns out to be hilarious and intense
item.description: From the archives: Ars talks to the filmmakers who collaborated with an AI for Sunspring.

item.title: The SolarWinds hackers aren’t back—they never went away
item.description: A new phishing campaign is less an escalation than a regression to the mean.

item.title: Deepfake maps could really mess with your sense of the world
item.description: Researchers applied AI techniques to make portions of Seattle look more like Beijing

item.title: Heads up! The cardiovascular secrets of giraffes
item.description: Giraffes: Scary high blood pressure, yet few of the issues plaguing people with hypertension.

item.title: Amazon devices will soon automatically share your Internet with neighbors
item.description: Amazon’s experimental wireless mesh networking turns users into guinea pigs.

item.title: Ancient cemetery tells a tale of constant, low-level warfare
item.description: Men, women, and children were repeatedly wounded in skirmishes along the Upper Nile.

item.title: Stardew Valley: The Board Game—a loving production but a mixed review from Grandpa
item.description: The beloved video game is relaxing. The board game? Not as much.

item.title: Trinitite: The radioactive rock buried in New Mexico before the Atari games
item.description: From the archives: A short story about a strange glass.

item.title: Rewilding: Four tips to let nature thrive
item.description: Comprehensive international study on rewilding has practical tips to re-establish nature.

item.title: NASA budget goes all-in on science, stays the course on Moon lander
item.description: “The goal is 2024, but I think we have to be brutally realistic.”

item.title: AT&T/Verizon lobby keeps claiming that home-Internet prices are dropping
item.description: USTelecom’s “Broadband Pricing Index” doesn’t measure what the average user pays.

item.title: CDC loosened mask guidance to encourage vaccination—it failed spectacularly
item.description: FDA approval and paid time off would make people more likely to get a shot, poll finds.

item.title: Review: A Quiet Place Part 2 is a worthy sequel that was worth the wait
item.description: Paramount, director John Krasinski opted to shelve the movie until theaters reopened
